GUIDANCE NOTE FOR ECONOMIC EVALUATION OF CLIMATE CHANGE IMPACTS IN THE SAVA RIVER BASIN
1 Background The objective of the economic analysis is to measure the magnitude and distributional costs of climate change impacts and adaptation options under alternative water regime scenarios in the Sava River Basin (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Serbia and Slove- nia). This analysis aims to capture climate change impact at the sector and economy-wide lev- els. It builds on the main WATCAP report (World Bank, 2013b), the report on the development of future climate scenarios (Vujadinovic and Vukovic, 2013); on the report on development of the hydrologic model for the Sava River basin (World Bank, 2013a) presented as Annex 1 and also for the Agriculture Guidance Note presented as Annex 5.
2 Framework The Sava connects three South-European capitals: Ljubljana in Slovenia, Zagreb in Croatia and Belgrade in Serbia (Figure 1). It is 945 km long and drains 95,719 kmÂ² of surface area.

This study adopts an integrated approach combining crop modelling with economy-wide analy- sis:

Hence different components developed in this analysis where:
ï‚· Economic baseline refer to the most likely growth path that the SRB countries are expected to follow based on the published forecasts from the World Bank, IMF and USDA studies. ï‚· Climate scenarios are developed on the basis of various trends regarding the pace and amplitude of Climate Change impact on the SRB. ï‚· Crop modeling is based on historic climate variables and climate projections. ï‚· Adaptation Plan (AP) recommendations on various potential adaptation policies are devel- oped using the CGE model on the basis of the climate and crop modelsâ€™ assumptions.
The analytical methods and data used in this analysis aim to provide a basis for the preparation of guidance notes on the economic analysis of climate change and Adaptation Plans (AP) which are also planned to be incorporated into the Water and Climate Change projects in ECA.
3 Description of the Sector/economy-wide level analysis The economic analysis focuses on the macro-level impacts of climate change through country and inter-regional computable general equilibrium analyses (CGE)3. 30 years continuous data for selected climate variables was collected.
The results from 5 GCM model analyses are introduced into the CGE model. Overall impact on SRB countriesâ€™ GDP, consumption and agricultural productions were estimated for the next 55+ years.
4 Drivers of economic growth Data was retrieved from the IMF World Economic Outlook database for the SRB countries: Al- bania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Serbia and Slovenia. The database used in the CGE modelling (GTAP) has 2007 as the reference year, the simulation exercises are conducted over the period 2010- 2070. This paper presents (i) available published statistics for the period 2007-2013, (ii) how they are used as inputs for the model simulations, and (iii) pre- liminary simulations results till 2070.

Model Baseline simulations consist of using the CGE model to replicate the SRB countriesâ€™ growth performances predicted by the IMF for 2004-2015, these projections are extended to 2070 using information from different sources (e.g. USDA). This exercise comprises three steps:

Using the WATCAP model, Climate Change impact is translated into yield changes for each crop produced in different SRB countries in the horizon to 2040 and 2070.
These yield changes are introduced as productivity (TFP) shocks into the CGE model. These generate a ripple effect through price changes which will be reflected to the market prices of analyzed crops which down the line will have an impact on consumer welfare, external trade and growth.

doc.repnme: Water and climate adaptation plan for the Sava river basin
doc.abstracts: This report presents the water and climate adaptation plan (WATCAP) developed for the Sava river basin (SRB) as result of a study undertaken by the World Bank. The WATCAP is intended to help to bridge the gap between the climate change predictions for the SRB and the decision makers in current and planned water management investment projects that will be affected by changing climate trends. The purpose of the report is to: (i) assist stakeholders and decision makers in assessing and planning for the risks generated by climate change impacts on water resources; (ii) provide a basis for future plans and studies of adaptation to climate change impacts in the SRB; and (iii) stimulate cooperation and debate across the basin toward additional and more detailed studies on climate change impacts at the regional and basin scale. The SRB is projected to experience small increases in water use by the public water supply, industry, energy, and agricultural and irrigation sectors. However, it is widely expected that new hydropower plants (HPPs) will be constructed in the near future, making energy (primarily through hydropower) the most important water use in the SRB.
